choices.text: It is a sexually transmitted disease.
It is transmitted by fomites.
It has a mother-to-child transmission route.
Periostitis is a manifestation of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Yaws?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periostitis is a manifestation of the disease.

 

Option D:

 

Yaws is a chronic infection that primarily affects the skin, bones, and cartilage. Periostitis, is a well-known manifestation of the disease, especially in its early stages. Periostitis may result in nocturnal bone pain

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Yaws is not a sexually transmitted disease; it is transmitted through direct skin contact.

 

Option B. Transmission by fomites is not a common mode of transmission for Yaws.

 

Option C. Mother-to-child transmission is not the usual route for Yaws; it generally occurs through direct nonsexual contact with the exudate from infectious lesions.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical Manifestation of Yaws 

 

Primary lesion (“Mother yaw”): Extragenital papule on extremities that enlarges in moist warm weather to become papillomatous or raspberry-like; Regional lymphadenopathy. Secondary eruptions are more generalized. Skin lesions may take several forms such as macular, papular, or papillomatous. Painful lesions on the feet result in a crab-like gait (“Crab yaws”). 

 

Late yaws occurs in 10% of untreated persons, and is manifested by destructive lesions (Gumma) of skin, bone, and joints. Destruction of the nose, maxilla, palate and pharynx (Gangosa). Relapses are common during the first 5 years.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p380,2/e p394-395

choices.text: Both pulmonary and central nervous system tuberculosis
Both central nervous system and disseminated tuberculosis

questions.text:
A 3-month-old male infant presents to the clinic for a routine well-child visit. His parents are healthcare workers and are concerned about tuberculosis (TB) exposure. They inquire about the Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine and its protective effects against various forms of TB.

 

Question: Which form of tuberculosis does the Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine offer the most protection against in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both central nervous system and disseminated tuberculosis

 

Option C:

 

The Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine is known to offer variable protection against pulmonary TB but is most effective in preventing severe forms of TB in children, such as miliary TB and TB meningitis, which are categorized as disseminated and central nervous system TB, respectively.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pulmonary tuberculosis - While BCG may provide some protection against pulmonary TB, it is not the form against which it is maximally protective.

 

Option B. Both pulmonary and central nervous system tuberculosis - BCG is more protective against CNS and disseminated TB than pulmonary TB alone.

 

Option D. Extrapulmonary tuberculosis - BCG is particularly protective against CNS TB, which is a type of extrapulmonary TB, but not all forms of extrapulmonary TB are equally protected by BCG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BCG vaccine is the most protective against central nervous system and disseminated forms of tuberculosis in children.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p 294

choices.text: It belongs to a new class of antibacterial drugs.
Its mechanism of action involves ATP synthase inhibition.
It is typically prescribed for a 12-month schedule.
It is highly efficient as a solo-drug regimen.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman with a history of chronic cough and weight loss has been diagnosed with multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) after failing first-line therapy. She is now being considered for a second-line treatment regimen.

 

Question: Which of the following statements is true regarding bedaquiline, a medication used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Its mechanism of action involves ATP synthase inhibition.

 

Option B:

 

Bedaquiline is a new class of antibacterial drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthase. It is used for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) when an effective treatment regimen cannot otherwise be composed for reasons of resistance or tolerability. However, the key distinguishing feature of bedaquiline is its unique mechanism of action, which targets ATP synthase, thereby reducing the energy production required for the mycobacterium to survive.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While bedaquiline is a new antibacterial class, this is less specific than its mechanism of action.

 

Option C. Bedaquiline is recommended for 24 weeks as part of combination therapy, not typically for a 12-month schedule.

 

Option D. Bedaquiline should not be used as a solo-drug regimen due to the risk of resistance development and is less effective when used alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline

 

  • Diarylquinoline drug which targets Mycobacterial ATP synthase
  • Extended half-life: Present even 5.5 months after stoppage
  • Significant use in culture-conversion time for MDR-TB
  • Patient selection criteria: Age 18 years or more with MDR-TB
  • Contraindications: Pregnancy, Cardiac arrhythmia

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology2/e p293

questions.text:
A public health officer is tasked with evaluating the digital tools used for the management of tuberculosis (TB) cases in a region with a high prevalence of the disease. They are assessing various software options to improve the monitoring and reporting of TB treatment outcomes.

 

Question: Which of the following software applications is the newly introduced tool by the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP) for online TB monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nikshay

 

Option A:

 

Nikshay is a web-enabled patient management system for TB control under the RNTCP. It is an initiative to facilitate online recording and reporting of TB patients' data and is used for monitoring of TB patients along with the provision of various directly observed treatment (DOT) services.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Nirbhaya - This is not related to TB monitoring and is more associated with women's safety initiatives.

 

Option C. e-DOT - While suggestive of TB treatment monitoring, e-DOT is not the specific tool introduced by RNTCP.

 

Option D. Nischay - This is a slight misspelling of the correct answer and may be a distractor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nikshay is the online software application for TB monitoring introduced by the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP).

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med.Microbiology 2/e p293

choices.text: The patient is on ATT and has a positive sputum smear after 5 months.
The patient is on ATT and has a positive sputum smear after 2 months.
The patient is on ATT and has a positive sputum smear after 4 months.
The patient initially had a negative sputum smear but became positive after 4 months of ATT.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female with a persistent cough and fever is undergoing treatment for tuberculosis (TB). Despite adherence to antitubercular therapy (ATT), her symptoms have not improved, and recent sputum smears continue to be positive.

 

Question: When should a patient be considered a suspect for multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The patient is on ATT and has a positive sputum smear after 2 months.

 

Option B:

 

A patient is suspected of having MDR-TB if there is a lack of conversion of the sputum smear from positive to negative after two months of ATT, indicating potential resistance to the drugs being administered.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Positive smear after 5 months is concerning, but suspicion for MDR-TB generally arises earlier.

 

Option C: Positive smear after 4 months also raises concern; however, the key timeframe for suspecting MDR-TB is after 2 months.

 

Option D: A change from negative to positive could indicate a new infection or laboratory error and would need further investigation, not immediately suggesting MDR-TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Positive sputum smear after 2 months of antitubercular therapy is indicative of a potential multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) infection.

 

Ref: RNTCP Guidelines on Programmatic Management of MDR TB in India

questions.text:
A 30-year-old patient presents with a chronic cough and night sweats. A sputum sample has been sent to the laboratory for analysis, and the clinician is reviewing the microbiological characteristics to establish a diagnosis.

 

Question: Which bacterium is most consistently associated with acid-fast bacilli on sputum smear, a common finding in active pulmonary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

Option C:

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the causative agent of tuberculosis and is characterized by acid-fast bacilli on sputum smear due to the mycolic acid in its cell wall, which is detected by acid-fast staining.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes - This is a Gram-positive bacterium and is not acid-fast.

 

Option B. Nocardia asteroids - While Nocardia species are also acid-fast, they are less commonly associated with the classic presentation of TB.

 

Option D. Corynebacterium diphtheriae - This bacterium causes diphtheria, not tuberculosis, and is not usually identified by acid-fast staining.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis as the bacterium most consistently associated with acid-fast bacilli on sputum smear in active pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p276

questions.text:
In a clinic serving a population with a high prevalence of HIV/AIDS, a 29-year-old patient presents with fever, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea. The patient has a low CD4 count and is being evaluated for opportunistic infections.

 

Question: Which of the following tests would be most appropriate to screen for an opportunistic infection commonly associated with HIV/AIDS using urine samples?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

Option D:

 

The detection of lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen in urine is used to screen for tuberculosis, especially in patients with HIV/AIDS, due to its ease of collection and rapid results. This test is particularly useful in resource-limited settings and for patients with advanced immunosuppression.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii - Diagnosis is usually made by identifying cysts in respiratory specimens, not urine.

 

Option B. Cryptococcus neoformans - While cryptococcal antigen can be detected in blood or cerebrospinal fluid, it is not typically screened in urine.

 

Option C. Toxoplasma gondii - This parasite is diagnosed through serological tests, not urine tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The detection of lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen in urine is used to screen for tuberculosis, especially in patients with HIV/AIDS

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p278

questions.text:
A healthcare worker in a high burden TB setting is evaluating diagnostic tests for tuberculosis (TB) to ensure rapid and accurate diagnosis for prompt initiation of treatment.

 

Question: Which of the following laboratory tests for Mycobacterium tuberculosis requires only whole blood as a sample?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interferon Gamma Release Assay (IGRA)

 

Option C:

 

The Interferon Gamma Release Assay (IGRA) is a blood test that measures the immune response to the TB bacteria in whole blood. It is used to diagnose latent TB infection and is an alternative to the tuberculin skin test.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluorescent staining - This requires respiratory samples, not blood.

 

Option B. GeneXpert MTB - This rapid molecular test also requires respiratory specimens.

 

Option D. ZN staining - The Ziehl-Neelsen stain is used on b, not blood, to identify acid-fast bacilli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Interferon Gamma Release Assay (IGRA) is the laboratory test for TB that utilizes whole blood as a sample.

 

Ref:  Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p279, 2/e p291

questions.text:
A lab technician receives two sputum samples from a patient who is being evaluated for tuberculosis (TB) as part of a screening program. The samples were collected at different times to increase the sensitivity of the sputum smear microscopy.

 

Question: How are two sputum samples of a TB suspect labeled when one is given at the spot and the other is collected the following morning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 2

 

Option B:

 

In TB diagnostics, especially within programs following the RNTCP guidelines, sputum samples are labeled in a chronological order to maintain the sequence of collection. The first sample collected on the spot is usually labeled as '1' or 'spot', and the second sample collected the next morning is labeled as '2' or 'morning'.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A and B - This bis not typically used for sputum samples in TB diagnostics.

 

Option C. Alpha and Beta - Similar to A and B, this is not the standard labeling convention.

 

Option D. Y and Z - These labels are not standard for sputum sample collection in TB diagnostics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The labeling system for sputum samples in tuberculosis diagnostics, with the first sample labeled as '1' and the second as '2'.

 

Ref:   NTEP manual for laboratory technicians

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male with a history of chronic smoking presents with dyspnea and left-sided chest pain. A pleural effusion is suspected, and pleural fluid is sent to the laboratory for analysis to rule out tuberculosis (TB).

 

Question: Which of the following tests cannot be used to measure a parameter from pleural fluid in a suspected case of tuberculosis (TB)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gene Xpert

 

Option A:

 

Gene Xpert (Xpert MTB/RIF) is a molecular test that identifies DNA sequences specific for Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance. It is typically performed on sputum samples, not pleural fluid, to diagnose pulmonary TB and assess for drug resistance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) - Elevated in pleural fluid due to exudative effusions, including TB.

 

Option C. Albumin - Used to differentiate between exudative and transudative pleural effusions.

 

Option D. Adenosine deaminase (ADA) - Elevated levels in pleural fluid are highly suggestive of TB pleuritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gene Xpert is typically used for analyzing sputum sample, not pleural fluid, in suspected cases of TB.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p278, 2/e p288

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a productive cough and night sweats is undergoing diagnostic evaluation for suspected pulmonary tuberculosis. The laboratory is prepared to perform staining techniques on her sputum samples. Which of the following stains are used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in sputum samples?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Auramine

 

Option A:

 

Auramine stain is a  fluorescent that are specifically used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis due to the mycolic acids in the bacterial cell wall.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Gram stain - This is a broad-spectrum stain that is not specific for acid-fast organisms like Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Giemsa stain - Typically used for the detection of parasites and certain bacteria, but not for TB.

 

Option D. Albert's stain - Used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auramine and Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) stains as specific staining techniques used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials ofMedical Microbiology/p276, 2/e p286

questions.text:
A 33-year-old male with a history of a positive tuberculin skin test but no active tuberculosis (TB) symptoms is being evaluated for latent TB infection to determine the need for prophylactic treatment.

 

Question: Which agent is used in the interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ESAT-6 (Early Secreted Antigenic Target 6)

 

Option D:

 

The interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs) for latent tuberculosis infection utilize antigens like ESAT-6 and CFP-10 (Culture Filtrate Protein 10) to stimulate T-cells in blood samples. These antigens are specific to Mycobacterium tuberculosis and do not cross-react with the BCG vaccine strain or most non-tuberculous mycobacteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MPT 64 - A protein associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex but not used in IGRA.

 

Option B. Mycolic acid - A component of the mycobacterial cell wall, not used in IGRA.

 

Option C. Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) - A cell wall component detectable in urine, not used in IGRA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ESAT-6 is the specific antigen used in interferon-gamma release assays for diagnosing latent tuberculosis infection.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p279, 2/e p291

choices.text: Monitoring drug response in MDR TB

questions.text:
A 22-year-old male patient with a persistent cough and history of close contact with a TB patient is undergoing diagnostic evaluation. The clinician has ordered a rapid molecular test to assess for tuberculosis and potential drug resistance.

 

Question: What is the primary use of the Xpert MTB/RIF test in the clinical setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assessing rifampicin resistance and E. Diagnosis of TB

 

Option C:

 

The Xpert MTB/RIF assay is a rapid molecular test that can diagnose both tuberculosis infection and assess for rifampicin resistance, which is a surrogate marker for MDR-TB, within hours.

 

GeneXpert (CBNAAT)

 

GeneXpert (Cepheid’s) is the CBNAAT system endorsed by WHO and is used in India under RNTCP 

 

 

  • It has the lowest turnaround time (2 hours) among all the diagnostic methods currently available for TB
  • Principle: It is based on real-time PCR technique; simultaneously detects: (i) MTB complex DNA, and (ii) rifampicin resistance (mutations of the rpoB gene). It uses five probes targeting various sequences of rpoB gene
  • WHO recommends GeneXpert as the initial test for diagnosis of EPTB; especially for CSF, lymph nodes and other tissue specimens. 

 

Next generation GeneXpert (Xpert Ultra): It is more sensitive and specific than GeneXpert, with a detection limit of 16 bacilli/mL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Assessing resistance to isoniazid - While important, this is not what the Xpert test is designed for.

 

Option B. Assessing multidrug-resistant TB - Rifampicin resistance is a key marker for MDR-TB, but the test does not assess resistance to other drugs.

 

Option D. Monitoring drug response in MDR TB - The test is not used to monitor treatment response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary uses of the Xpert MTB/RIF test in clinical settings, includes the rapid diagnosis of TB and the assessment of rifampicin resistance, simultaneously.

 

Ref: CDC website; Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 2/e p288

questions.text: A patient presents with atypical pneumonia symptoms and a high clinical suspicion for Mycoplasma infection. Given the unique characteristics of Mycoplasma species, which of the following antibiotics would be ineffective due to the organism's resistance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ceftriaxone

 

Option A:

 

Mycoplasma species, including Mycoplasma pneumoniae, are intrinsically resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics like ceftriaxone because they lack a cell wall, which is the target of beta-lactam antibiotics. This lack of cell wall prevents the beta-lactam antibiotics from exerting their effect, which is to inhibit cell wall synthesis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Doxycycline is effective against Mycoplasma because it inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.

 

Option C: Azithromycin, a macrolide, is effective against Mycoplasma due to its action on the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibition of protein synthesis.

 

Option D: Levofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, is effective against Mycoplasma by inhibiting DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycoplasma species are resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics like ceftriaxone because they lack a cell wall, making it an ineffective choice for treating Mycoplasma infections

 

Ref:  Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1e/p408, 2/e p424

choices.text: To delay the development of drug resistance
To reduce the toxicity of individual drugs
To broaden the antimicrobial spectrum
To prevent the release of toxins from the dying bacteria

questions.text: During the management of a patient with newly diagnosed pulmonary tuberculosis, the importance of multidrug therapy is being discussed. Which of the following is the primary reason for using a combination of drugs in the treatment of tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) To delay the development of drug resistance

 

Option A:

 

The main rationale for multidrug therapy in tuberculosis is to prevent the development of drug resistance. Mycobacterium tuberculosis has a high capacity for developing resistance to monotherapy, therefore a combination of drugs is used to ensure that the bacteria are attacked by different mechanisms, reducing the chance for resistance mutations to confer a survival advantage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Reducing toxicity is a benefit of multidrug therapy, but not the primary reason for its use in tuberculosis.

 

Option C. The antimicrobial spectrum of tuberculosis therapy is already targeted to the mycobacteria, so broadening the spectrum is not the primary concern.

 

Option D. Preventing toxin release is not relevant to tuberculosis therapy, as the bacteria do not release toxins that contribute to disease pathology in the way that some other bacteria do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary reason for multidrug therapy in tuberculosis is to prevent the development of drug resistance, which is a major challenge in the management of this disease. 

 

MDR Suspect Criteria to initiate DS

 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p281, 2/e p291, Park 23/e p192, 24/e p196-197

questions.text: An infectious disease specialist discusses antibiotic resistance profiles during a seminar. Which antibiotic is Ureaplasma urealyticum naturally resistant to, complicating the treatment strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cephalosporins

 

Option C:

 

Ureaplasma urealyticum is naturally resistant to cephalosporins because it lacks a cell wall, which is the target of beta-lactam antibiotics such as cephalosporins.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Erythromycin is an effective treatment option for Ureaplasma infections.

 

Option B: Chloramphenicol could be effective, although it is not commonly used due to potential side effects.

 

Option D: Tetracyclines are commonly used to treat Ureaplasma infections and are effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureaplasma urealyticum is naturally resistant to cephalosporins because it lacks a cell wall, which is the target of beta-lactam antibiotics such as cephalosporins. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p405, 2/e p421, Ananthanarayan 9/e p389, 10/e p392-393

questions.text: A patient presents with atypical pneumonia not responding to beta-lactam antibiotics. The causative agent, historically referred to as the Eaton agent, requires cholesterol for growth and is known to be a frequent cause of community-acquired respiratory infections. Which organism is associated with this historical term?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycoplasma pneumoniae

 

Option A:

 

The Eaton agent refers to Mycoplasma pneumoniae, an atypical bacterium that is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia and requires cholesterol for growth, which distinguishes it from other bacterial pathogens.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Haemophilus influenzae is a cause of respiratory infections but is not known as the Eaton agent.

 

Option C: Klebsiella pneumoniae is a common cause of hospital-acquired pneumonia and not referred to as the Eaton agent.

 

Option D: Chlamydia pneumoniae, while a cause of atypical pneumonia, is not the Eaton agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycoplasma pneumoniae is historically known as the Eaton agent, which requires cholesterol for growth and is associated with atypical pneumonia.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p405, 2/e p421, Ananthanarayan 9/e p386, 10/e p392

choices.text: Growth on MacConkey agar without fermentation
A positive D-test for clindamycin resistance

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease presents with fever, confusion, and headache. His wife reports that he has had a decreased appetite and has been less active over the past week. On examination, he is febrile with a temperature of 38.7°C, neck stiffness is noted, and Brudzinski's sign is positive. Blood cultures are drawn, and he is started on empirical antibiotic therapy. The Gram stain of the CSF shows gram-positive rods. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be associated with the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tumbling motility at room temperature

 

Option B:

 

The patient's clinical presentation is suggestive of bacterial meningitis, and the CSF Gram stain showing gram-positive rods points towards Listeria monocytogenes, especially given the patient's advanced age and immunocompromised state. Listeria is characterized by tumbling motility at room temperature due to its flagella, which distinguishes it from other gram-positive rods that could also present in CSF. This feature, combined with the patient's risk factors, makes this the most likely diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Growth on MacConkey agar without fermentation is not characteristic of Listeria, as it does not grow well on this medium.

 

Option C: Urease production is not a feature of Listeria monocytogenes; it is associated with organisms like Proteus species.

 

Option D: A positive D-test for clindamycin resistance is associated with certain strains of staphylococci and streptococci, not Listeria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria should be considered in the differential diagnosis of meningitis in immunocompromised individuals and the elderly. It is characterized by tumbling motility at room temperature, which can be observed under a microscope. 

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p296

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a history of tuberculosis presents with flank pain and dysuria. Renal tuberculosis is suspected. Which of the following urine collection methods is most appropriate for the detection of renal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) First-morning urine specimen

 

Option C:

 

For the diagnosis of renal tuberculosis, the first-morning full void urine specimen; collected consecutively for 3 days,  is preferred because it allows for the concentration of bacilli, increasing the yield of acid-fast bacillus (AFB) smear and culture. This is particularly useful for cases where bacterial load is low, such as extrapulmonary tuberculosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 24-hour urine collection: Incorrect because it dilutes the bacterial load, making detection more difficult.

 

Option B. 12-hour urine collection: Incorrect for the same reason as the 24-hour collection; it dilutes the bacterial content.

 

Option D. Random urine specimen: Incorrect because the concentration of bacteria may not be as high as in the first-morning specimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-morning urine specimen is the preferred method for collecting urine when diagnosing renal tuberculosis due to the higher concentration of mycobacteria.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p278, 2/e p290

choices.text: To detect prior sensitization to tuberculous antigens
To assess the resistance of the patient to tuberculosis
To determine the susceptibility of the patient to tuberculosis

questions.text: A 22-year-old male who recently emigrated from a country with a high prevalence of tuberculosis is screened for Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. What is the primary purpose of performing a tuberculin skin test (TST) in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) To detect prior sensitization to tuberculous antigens

 

Option A:

 

The tuberculin skin test (TST), also known as the Mantoux test, is used to detect an individual's immune response to the tuberculin purified protein derivative (PPD), indicating prior sensitization to tuberculous proteins. This response may result from past or present infection with M. tuberculosis or from vaccination with Bacille Calmette-Guerin (BCG).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. To assess the resistance of the patient to tuberculosis: Incorrect because TST does not provide information on resistance to TB.

 

Option C. To determine the susceptibility of the patient to tuberculosis: Incorrect because TST does not determine susceptibility, but rather whether there has been an immune response to TB antigens.

 

Option D. To diagnose active tuberculosis disease: Incorrect because TST does not differentiate between active and latent TB infection, and additional evaluation is needed to diagnose active disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculin Test - Is the prototype of delayed hypersensitivity. In sensitized individuals, (i.e. who possess sensitized TDTH cells due to prior contact with M. tuberculosis); when a preparation of tuberculin antigen (glycerol extract of the tubercle bacillus) is injected intradermally, a local reaction develops after 48–72 hours consisting of induration surrounded by erythema.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p279, 2/e p290, Park 23/e p185, 24/e p195

choices.text: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for H. pylori

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of epigastric pain. The pain is intermittent, worse at night, and relieved by eating. He has not taken any over-the-counter medications. On endoscopy, he has a duodenal ulcer. Biopsy specimens from the antrum are obtained. Which diagnostic test will most likely confirm the suspected etiology of his ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rapid urease test

 

Option A:

 

The rapid urease test is often performed on a biopsy from the gastric mucosa to detect Helicobacter pylori, the most common cause of duodenal ulcers. This organism produces urease, which hydrolyzes urea to ammonia and carbon dioxide, and can be rapidly identified with this test.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The urea breath test is a non-invasive test that can also confirm H. pylori infection but is not performed on biopsy specimens.

 

Option C: Serology for H. pylori can indicate past exposure but does not confirm active infection.

 

Option D: PCR for H. pylori is highly specific but not routinely used due to cost and is not as readily available as the urease test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate diagnostic test for Helicobacter pylori in a patient with a duodenal ulcer is the rapid urease test performed on gastric biopsy specimen. It is a quick and effective method for diagnosing active H. pylori infection.

 

Ref:  Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p364, 2/e p379
